text: good morning everyone my name is Shri
kot and as of about uh 10 weeks ago I'm
the uh new Chief technology officer at

users and uh you know a large part of my
internal Journey at Comcast really
parallels the work that we've been doing
to become what we think of as a as a
cloud native Product Company and what I
wanted to do was talk to you about what
that means why we think that's so
important and how Amazon has played such
a critical role in that
transition now most of you um aren't
used to hearing about Comcast uh at a
technology conference and so I wanted to
spend a minute telling you about the
company uh I think most of you probably
think of us as this big giant Media
Company a little bit scary and then you
know that's because well we we
are um so uh you know most uh if you
look at our if you look at the company
we did about $75 billion do in Revenue
last year the market cap of the company
is around 160 billion and um Wall Street
usually puts our peer group with
companies like Disney and Time Warner
and fox and Viacom uh but we think of
ourselves as very different than those
companies those are really companies
they are great companies but they're
really companies that are portfolios of
great brands at Comcast we really view
ourselves as a company that has a
mission and a mandate now there are two
big halves to the company the content
side NBC Universal which most people
know very well and then the exfinity
side which represents the service
provider side of the business and people
don't always appreciate and understand
the scale of the service provider side
of the business so of the $75 billion um
in Revenue that we do uh a full 2third
$50 billion comes from the service
provider side and about 34 of the
operating cash flow though the
profitability and growth comes from that
side of the business and in terms of
scale um that represents about 29
million households that we have a
relationship with that we power with one
or many of our services um and just to
give you an idea on the technology side
what that means um if you look at things
like IPv6 which we've been at the
Forefront of pushing it's been so
critical to us as a business because we
are literally out of ipv4 addresses in
fact in the world there are only two
entities that manage more ipv4 addresses
than Comcast one is the Department of
Def sense and the other is
China um and so you know we we operate
at this very very large scale and and
when we when I talk about the Mandate
and mission for the company we really
view technology as being Central vital
to the future of uh media and media
consumption and so we feel like standing
boldly at that intersection is going to
be very crucial to the success of the
company um a great example of this is
our X1 product um so X1 is our Flagship
video product if you sign up today as an
Infinity customer you'll get X1 um and
if you haven't used it and you have say
Apple TV or Fire TV or an Xbox I'm not
going to stand here and say you're going
to be blown away by what you see on X1
but I think I think you would be
surprise it's a premium Rich modern
experience um I think you would look at
it and go yeah you know what that's what
television ought to be like in 2016 um
and the Olympics is a great example of
that showcase and highlights why we
think this intersection is so important
the last time there was an Olympics um
in the United States in the sort of
Eastern Time Zone was in Atlanta about
20 years ago and at that time there were
200 hours of Olympics content that were
available basically over a twoe period
so basically you know four or five
channels four or five hours a day you
could basically watch all of that
content this year we're making available
6,800 hours of content if you try to
watch all of it every day every hour of
every day it would take you probably
about 3 300 days to watch all that
content um and and this is why having a
rich premium technology experience to
help you connect with that content to
find the teams that you love the
athletes that you're interested in the
countries that you care about is really
really critical and why um the
experience is so important and what
we've seen with X1 and this is going to
sound like an obvious dumb thing if
you're if you're from Silicon Valley but
what we've seen is that when you build
better products people spend more time
with you and when they spend more time
with you they spend more money with you
and that's what we've seen with the X1
experience U churn is massively reduced
people watch a lot more television 30 to
40% more they buy more services they buy
um you know three times as much DVR
subscriptions uh 30 to 40% more HBO
Cinemax all the premium services and
it's pretty easy if you build stuff that
people love they spend more time with
you and they forgive they forgive your
mistakes um and so let's look at as we
think about the transition to Cloud
native and what that means let's look at
a microcosm here so uh we launched last
year uh the X1 voice remote um so the X1
voice remote was launched in May of 2015
and we weren't sure how this product
would do it was built by a team about
2025 people we felt like uh you know it
might be a great thing to do but we
weren't sure if voice was really going
to um resonate for people in media
consumption experiences or it was going
to be a little bit more of a a toy for
Alpha Geeks like Siri or Okay Google and
so the original plan was our forecast
for 2015 was 10,000 voice remotes um a a
little over a year later um you know 15
16 months later it turns out we shipped
10 million voice remotes so we were off
by a factor of a
thousand um and and this this
opportunity the opportunity to try stuff
to be wrong and still deliver a
successful product in the marketplace is
a big part of what we think the cloud
enables in some in some profound ways
so if you look at X1 X1 is pretty much a
classic microservices architecture um
hundreds of services with a few
aggregation services that do
orchestration and Performance Management
and
reliability um and as we looked at
deploying these at scale you know X1 now
is running on close to 20 million
devices we found that of course we took
advantage of the basic elements of of
cloud storage Network and compute but
very very quickly that became
insufficient to gain the kind of
velocity and reliability that we wanted
and so we started to move up the stack
um we started initially using Dynamo DB
to externalize some of the state um we
use um Route 53 uh for managing
interestingly enough managing a fully
programmable deployment of tens of
thousands of VMS on a daily basis um
across both on Prem and uh public Cloud
infrastructure at Amazon um we started
using sqs and SNS as a as a messaging
bus
um and you know we started to to really
get into the value of what it means to
be Cloud native um and that also
afforded us some other opportunities and
so we're stared to to now really be able
to take advantage of Rich unique value
ad services and this is a big part of
the transition to Cloud instead of
having these fully closed um Solutions
where you had to pick and choose and
they were kind of the same across the
industry the software as a solution
model and in particular all of the
services that Amazon are providing allow
you to assemble this toolkit that let
you focus on the products and services
that let you differentiate so the latest
that we've been leaning into is kinesis
and uh my co my colleague Charles Hamill
is going to be talking in detail about
what we're doing with Kinesis and the
data streams later today um but really
kind of the point of all of this
is all the things that people talk about
when they say being Cloud native and
embracing hybrid Cloud are true you
really do get um Agile development and
when I say Agile development I don't
mean you know code burn downs and
Sprints I mean real agile concept to
customer right the time that you have an
idea until that customer gets it in your
hands can be measured now in what used
to be if you look at our old product
prx1 we used to ship a product probably
every 12 to 18 months so over a three or
4 year period a 3 to 5e period we' maybe
ship three or four releases now we ship
three releases every week um so we can
have an idea we can make a change this
will happen even over the course of the
Olympics we'll make adjustments to the
features and modify stuff and get it
into across 20 million devices over the
course of an hour developers can go and
that happens at Large Scale it can also
happen at small scale developers and
product managers can work on features
and then have them running in their
houses that evening when they go home
and this obviously enables autonomous
team teams it massively accelerates
feature velocity and of course it
enables that that reduction to
change as wner talked about um to do
that you know unless you're starting
Greenfield unless you're a startup
unless you're you know coming from
nowhere you really do have to think
about what a hybrid model looks like and
what that Journey uh entails and
certainly all of the things that he
touched on are are critical you have to
think about how you're doing integrated
networking you have to think about the
data integration life cycle management
security and access controls become an
interesting problem and uh you know
taking advantage of of AWS vpcs become
critical in that model and of course you
think about integrated resource and
deployment and management models and we
have going through this journey over the
last uh 5 years we've realized the
benefits here and these benefits are
around cost and scale and they're
critical and they're important but
interestingly they're not the compelling
bit they're not the bit that gets us
excited about uh AWS and gets us excited
about uh about the
future um the key parts that we get
excited about is that this really
changes your Innovation cycle it really
fundamentally shifts how you think about
product development one of the classic
project management time space tradeoffs
has always been velocity or quality and
what we found is that that's no longer
the case you can have velocity and
quality if you look at over the last
three months we've shipped more features
than we had shipped in our old product
over the course of three years and at
the same time we've dramatically
increased the quality of the product so
if you look at the last three years
running as we made the transition to the
X1 product platform and to This Cloud
native model we've reduced we've
increase the quality and reduce trouble
tickets by 50% year-over-year every year
so less calls less tickets and massive
increase in uh massive increase in
feature velocity um and this ultimately
is really the point it creates an
opportunity for differentiation and
we've seen this realized in the
marketplace this isn't theoretical if
you look at what we've done with the X1
product platform q1 of this year we had
the best video quarter that we've had in
nine years in Q2 we had the best video
quarter that we've had in 10 years um
and we expect that pace to continue um
we've really been able to take all of
the products and services and increase
the usage uh reduce the churn and really
Drive real business value it's not just
about the cost reduction it's about
changing those Innovation Cycles
fundamentally the message uh I would say
to you is that um the cloud changes here
it's not just an option it's the future
you can embrace it or you can be
